Title: Example 4.1
Body Text: Name the fraction of the shape that is shaded.

Title: Count the total parts
Body Text: First, count the total number of equal parts the shape is divided into. This will be your denominator.

Title: Count the shaded parts
Body Text: Next, count only the parts that are shaded. This will be your numerator.

Title: Write the fraction
Body Text: Place the number of shaded parts over the total number of parts: $$\frac{\text{shaded}}{\text{total}}$$ (3 shaded over 8 total).

Title: Try It 4.1
Body Text: Name the fraction of the shape that is shaded.

Title: Total parts
Body Text: The circle is divided into 4 equal parts.

Title: Shaded parts
Body Text: 3 parts are shaded.

Title: Try It 4.2
Body Text: Name the fraction of the shape that is shaded.

Title: Total parts
Body Text: The circle is divided into 5 equal parts.

Title: Shaded parts
Body Text: 3 parts are shaded.

Title: Example 4.2
Body Text: Name the fraction of the shape that is shaded.

Title: Total parts
Body Text: Count how many equal sections the rectangle is split into.

Title: Shaded parts
Body Text: Count how many of those sections are colored in.

Title: Try It 4.3
Body Text: Name the fraction of the shape that is shaded.

Title: Total parts
Body Text: The rectangle has 5 equal parts.

Title: Shaded parts
Body Text: 2 parts are shaded.

Title: Try It 4.4
Body Text: Name the fraction of the shape that is shaded.

Title: Total parts
Body Text: The rectangle has 8 equal parts.

Title: Shaded parts
Body Text: 3 parts are shaded.

Title: Example 4.3
Body Text: Name the improper fraction modeled. Then write the improper fraction as a mixed number.

Title: Improper Fraction
Body Text: First, identify the improper fraction. How many pieces is each whole circle divided into? (This is your denominator). Count the total shaded pieces (This is your numerator).

Title: Mixed Number
Body Text: Now, look at the whole shapes. How many full circles are shaded? What fraction of the last circle is shaded? Write this as a mixed number.

Title: Denominator
Body Text: Each circle is divided into 3 equal pieces, so the denominator is 3.

Title: Numerator
Body Text: There are 5 shaded pieces in total, so the numerator is 5.

Title: Try It 4.5
Body Text: Name the improper fraction modeled. Then write the improper fraction as a mixed number.

Title: Improper Fraction
Body Text: Write the improper fraction.

Title: Mixed Number
Body Text: Write the mixed number.

Title: Denominator
Body Text: Each circle is divided into 4 pieces.

Title: Numerator
Body Text: There are 7 shaded pieces in total.

Title: Try It 4.6
Body Text: Name the improper fraction modeled. Then write the improper fraction as a mixed number.

Title: Improper Fraction
Body Text: Write the improper fraction.

Title: Mixed Number
Body Text: Write the mixed number.

Title: Denominator
Body Text: Each circle is cut into halves (2 pieces).

Title: Numerator
Body Text: There are 5 halves shaded in total.

Title: Example 4.4a
Body Text: Use fraction circles to make wholes with 3 halves. How many wholes and how many halves are left over? (e.g., '1 whole and 1 half')

Title: Model
Body Text: A whole is 2 halves (2/2).

Title: Calculate
Body Text: 3 halves is 2/2 + 1/2. This is 1 whole and 1/2 left over.

Title: Example 4.4b
Body Text: Use fraction circles to make wholes with 8 fifths. How many wholes and how many fifths are left over? (e.g., '1 whole and 3 fifths')

Title: Model
Body Text: A whole is 5 fifths (5/5).

Title: Calculate
Body Text: 8 fifths is 5/5 + 3/5. This is 1 whole and 3/5 left over.

Title: Example 4.4c
Body Text: Use fraction circles to make wholes with 7 thirds. How many wholes and how many thirds are left over? (e.g., '2 wholes and 1 third')

Title: Model
Body Text: A whole is 3 thirds (3/3). How many groups of 3 are in 7?

Title: Calculate
Body Text: 7 thirds is 3/3 + 3/3 + 1/3. This is 2 wholes and 1/3 left over.

Title: Example 4.5
Body Text: Name the improper fraction modeled. Then write the improper fraction as a mixed number.

Title: Improper Fraction
Body Text: Each circle is divided into three pieces. How many pieces are shaded in total?

Title: Mixed Number
Body Text: How many whole circles are shaded, and what fraction is left over?

Title: Example 4.7
Body Text: Use a model to rewrite the improper fraction $$\frac{11}{6}$$ as a mixed number.

Title: Model the Whole
Body Text: A whole is made of six sixths ($$\frac{6}{6}$$). How many whole groups of 6 sixths can you make from 11 sixths?

Title: Find the Remainder
Body Text: $$\frac{11}{6} = \frac{6}{6} + \frac{?}{6}$$ What is the remaining fraction?

Title: Try It 4.13
Body Text: Use a model to rewrite the improper fraction as a mixed number: $$\frac{9}{7}$$

Title: Model
Body Text: A whole is 7/7. How many 7/7s are in 9/7?

Title: Try It 4.14
Body Text: Use a model to rewrite the improper fraction as a mixed number: $$\frac{7}{5}$$

Title: Model
Body Text: A whole is 5/5. How many 5/5s are in 7/5?

Title: Example 4.8
Body Text: Use a model to rewrite the mixed number $$1\frac{4}{5}$$ as an improper fraction.

Title: Model the Whole
Body Text: The mixed number means 1 whole and 4 fifths. How many fifths are in 1 whole?

Title: Add the Parts
Body Text: $$1\frac{4}{5} = 1 + \frac{4}{5} = \frac{5}{5} + \frac{4}{5}$$ Now add the numerators.

Title: Try It 4.15
Body Text: Use a model to rewrite the mixed number as an improper fraction: $$1\frac{3}{8}$$

Title: Model
Body Text: The whole number 1 is 8/8. Add the fractional part.

Title: Try It 4.16
Body Text: Use a model to rewrite the mixed number as an improper fraction: $$1\frac{5}{6}$$

Title: Model
Body Text: The whole number 1 is 6/6. Add the fractional part.

Title: Example 4.9
Body Text: Convert $$\frac{11}{6}$$ to a mixed number.

Title: How to
Body Text: To convert an improper fraction to a mixed number, divide the denominator into the numerator.

Title: Divide
Body Text: What is 11 divided by 6? Write the answer as 'Quotient R Remainder' (e.g., '1 R 5').

Title: Write as mixed number
Body Text: The quotient is the whole number, the remainder is the new numerator, and the divisor is the denominator.

Title: Try It 4.17
Body Text: Convert the improper fraction to a mixed number: $$\frac{13}{7}$$

Title: Divide
Body Text: Divide 13 by 7.

Title: Quotient & Remainder
Body Text: What is the quotient and remainder? (Write as 'Q R R', e.g., '1 R 6').

Title: Write as mixed number
Body Text: Write the mixed number as 'Quotient remainder/divisor'.

Title: Try It 4.18
Body Text: Convert the improper fraction to a mixed number: $$\frac{14}{9}$$

Title: Divide
Body Text: Divide 14 by 9.

Title: Example 4.10
Body Text: Convert the improper fraction $$\frac{33}{8}$$ to a mixed number.

Title: Divide
Body Text: Divide the denominator (8) into the numerator (33).

Title: Quotient & Remainder
Body Text: What is 33 divided by 8? Write the answer as 'Quotient R Remainder' (e.g., '4 R 1').

Title: Write as mixed number
Body Text: The quotient is the whole number, the remainder is the new numerator, and the divisor is the denominator.

Title: Try It 4.19
Body Text: Convert the improper fraction to a mixed number: $$\frac{23}{7}$$

Title: Quotient & Remainder
Body Text: What is 23 divided by 7? Write the answer as 'Quotient R Remainder'.

Title: Try It 4.20
Body Text: Convert the improper fraction to a mixed number: $$\frac{48}{11}$$

Title: Quotient & Remainder
Body Text: What is 48 divided by 11? Write the answer as 'Quotient R Remainder'.

Title: Example 4.11
Body Text: Convert the mixed number $$4\frac{2}{3}$$ to an improper fraction.

Title: Step 1
Body Text: Multiply the whole number (4) by the denominator (3).

Title: Multiply
Body Text: What is 4 * 3?

Title: Step 2
Body Text: Add the numerator (2) to the product you just found (12).

Title: Add
Body Text: What is 12 + 2?

Title: Step 3
Body Text: Write the final sum (14) over the original denominator (3).

Title: Try It 4.21
Body Text: Convert the mixed number to an improper fraction: $$3\frac{5}{7}$$

Title: Step 1
Body Text: Multiply the whole number (3) by the denominator (7).

Title: Step 2
Body Text: Add the numerator (5) to that product.

Title: Step 3
Body Text: Write the final sum over the original denominator (7).

Title: Try It 4.22
Body Text: Convert the mixed number to an improper fraction: $$2\frac{7}{8}$$

Title: Step 1
Body Text: What is the whole number (2) multiplied by the denominator (8)?

Title: Step 2
Body Text: What is that product (16) plus the numerator (7)?

Title: Step 3
Body Text: Write the final sum (23) over the original denominator (8).

Title: Example 4.12
Body Text: Convert the mixed number $$10\frac{2}{7}$$ to an improper fraction.

Title: Step 1
Body Text: What is 10 * 7?

Title: Step 2
Body Text: What is 70 + 2?

Title: Step 3
Body Text: Write the final sum (72) over the original denominator (7).

Title: Try It 4.23
Body Text: Convert the mixed number to an improper fraction: $$4\frac{6}{11}$$

Title: Step 1
Body Text: Multiply whole number (4) by denominator (11).

Title: Step 2
Body Text: Add the product (44) to the numerator (6).

Title: Step 3
Body Text: Write this sum over the original denominator (11).

Title: Try It 4.24
Body Text: Convert the mixed number to an improper fraction: $$11\frac{1}{3}$$

Title: Step 1
Body Text: What is 11 * 3?

Title: Step 2
Body Text: What is 33 + 1?

Title: Step 3
Body Text: Write 34 over the original denominator 3.

Title: Example 4.13a
Body Text: How many eighths equal one-half?

Title: Model
Body Text: Look at the fraction tile model. How many 1/8 tiles does it take to match the 1/2 tile?

Title: Algebra
Body Text: You are finding an equivalent fraction: $$\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{8}$$. Multiply the numerator (1) by the same number you multiply the denominator (2) by to get 8.

Title: Example 4.13b
Body Text: How many tenths equal one-half?

Title: Algebra
Body Text: You are finding an equivalent fraction: $$\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{10}$$. Multiply the numerator (1) by 5, since 2 * 5 = 10.

Title: Example 4.13c
Body Text: How many twelfths equal one-half?

Title: Algebra
Body Text: You are finding an equivalent fraction: $$\frac{1}{2} = \frac{?}{12}$$. Multiply the numerator (1) by 6, since 2 * 6 = 12.

Title: Try It 4.25
Body Text: How many eighths equal one-fourth?

Title: Algebra
Body Text: Find the equivalent fraction: $$\frac{1}{4} = \frac{?}{8}$$

Title: Try It 4.26
Body Text: How many twelfths equal one-fourth?

Title: Algebra
Body Text: Find the equivalent fraction: $$\frac{1}{4} = \frac{?}{12}$$

Title: Example 4.14
Body Text: Find three fractions equivalent to $$\frac{2}{5}$$.

Title: How-to
Body Text: To find an equivalent fraction, multiply the numerator and the denominator by the same number (but not zero).

Title: Multiply by 2
Body Text: What is $$\frac{2 \cdot 2}{5 \cdot 2}$$?

Title: Multiply by 3
Body Text: What is $$\frac{2 \cdot 3}{5 \cdot 3}$$?

Title: Multiply by 5
Body Text: What is $$\frac{2 \cdot 5}{5 \cdot 5}$$?

Title: Try It 4.27
Body Text: Find one fraction equivalent to $$\frac{3}{5}$$.

Title: How-to
Body Text: Multiply the numerator (3) and the denominator (5) by the same whole number (like 2, 3, or 4).

Title: Try It 4.28
Body Text: Find one fraction equivalent to $$\frac{4}{5}$$.

Title: How-to
Body Text: Multiply the numerator (4) and the denominator (5) by the same whole number (like 2, 3, or 4).

Title: Example 4.15
Body Text: Find a fraction with a denominator of 21 that is equivalent to $$\frac{2}{7}$$.

Title: Find the multiplier
Body Text: To get a denominator of 21, what number must you multiply 7 by?

Title: Find multiplier
Body Text: What is 21 divided by 7?

Title: Multiply
Body Text: Multiply both the numerator (2) and the denominator (7) by 3.

Title: Try It 4.29
Body Text: Find a fraction with a denominator of 21 that is equivalent to $$\frac{6}{7}$$.

Title: Find the multiplier
Body Text: To get a denominator of 21, what number must you multiply 7 by? (21 รท 7 = ?)

Title: Multiply
Body Text: Multiply both the numerator (6) and the denominator (7) by that number.

Title: Try It 4.30
Body Text: Find a fraction with a denominator of 100 that is equivalent to $$\frac{3}{10}$$.

Title: Find the multiplier
Body Text: To get a denominator of 100, what number must you multiply 10 by? (100 รท 10 = ?)

Title: Multiply
Body Text: Multiply both the numerator (3) and the denominator (10) by that number.

Title: Example 4.18a
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-1 \_\_ -\frac{2}{3}$$

Title: Number Line
Body Text: -1 is to the left of -2/3 on the number line, so -1 is less than -2/3.

Title: Example 4.18b
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-3\frac{1}{2} \_\_ -3$$

Title: Number Line
Body Text: -3 1/2 is to the left of -3 on the number line, so it is less than -3.

Title: Example 4.18c
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-\frac{3}{7} \_\_ -\frac{3}{8}$$

Title: Number Line
Body Text: When comparing negative fractions, the fraction with the larger denominator is actually closer to 0. -3/8 is to the right of -3/7, so -3/7 is less than -3/8.

Title: Example 4.18d
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-2 \_\_ -\frac{16}{9}$$

Title: Convert
Body Text: First, convert the improper fraction -16/9 to a mixed number.

Title: Convert
Body Text: What is -16/9 as a mixed number?

Title: Number Line
Body Text: -2 is to the left of -1 7/9 on the number line, so -2 is less than -1 7/9.

Body Text: Since both denominators are the same, compare the numerators. -5 is to the right of -7 on the number line, so -5/12 is greater.

Title: Exercise 69
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-\frac{9}{10} \_\_ -\frac{3}{10}$$

Title: Number Line
Body Text: Since the denominators are the same, compare the numerators. -9 is to the left of -3 on the number line, so -9/10 is smaller.

Title: Exercise 70
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-3 \_\_ -\frac{13}{5}$$

Title: Convert
Body Text: First, convert the improper fraction to a mixed number.

Title: Convert
Body Text: What is -13/5 as a mixed number?

Title: Number Line
Body Text: -3 is to the left of -2 3/5 on the number line, so -3 is smaller.

Title: Exercise 71
Body Text: Order the pair of numbers using < or >: $$-4 \_\_ -\frac{23}{6}$$

Title: Convert
Body Text: First, convert the improper fraction to a mixed number.

Body Text: -4 is to the left of -3 5/6 on the number line, so -4 is smaller.

Title: Exercise 72
Body Text: A choreographed dance is broken into counts. A 1/1 count has one step in a count, a 1/2 count has two steps in a count and a 1/3 count has three steps in a count. How many steps would be in a 1/5 count?

Title: Pattern
Body Text: The denominator of the fraction tells you how many steps are in the count.

Title: Exercise 73
Body Text: In 4/4 time, there are four quarter notes in one measure. How many measures would eight quarter notes make?

Title: Divide
Body Text: Divide the total number of quarter notes (8) by the number of notes per measure (4).

Title: Exercise 74
Body Text: For each pan, she needs 1/2 cup of walnuts. How many cups of walnuts does she need for five pans of fudge?

Title: Multiply
Body Text: Multiply the number of pans (5) by the amount of walnuts per pan (1/2).
